review_title: Lots of change coming for the better
job_title: Academic Advisor in King of Prussia, PA
pros: Within the last year the company has been involved in internal restructuring to make the client experience more outstanding; however, there are major benefits for the staff as well. Advisors can be considered more subject matter experts rather than a 'call center rep' standard.
cons: Change can be slow and staff must be patient to withstand the time it takes for things to be implemented. It stunts professional growth/internal promotion.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bryn Mawr, PA
pros: I genuinely like my job and I'm not looking to move up the ladder to a VP but I would like to stay where I am, and continue to grow into other roles, but that is definitely a possibility here.
cons: Pay is low, comp project is a big joke.  No education opportunities for actual skills training.  We would like to learn how to use PeopleSoft and Microsoft Office better, but our requests seem to fall on deaf ears.   I feel like this place may be hurting careers because what we do does not transfer externally.  None of our titles or even jobs that we do can be translated outside of this place, unless you are IT.  We even have a few people whose main job is to walk around and pretend to be busy all day and collect a paycheck.  Lunch with the president is a joke because the HR leader sits and takes notes which does not promote a safe environment.  The president dismissing remarks made at the lunch shows that he is not open to listening to the truth and the way that any issues have been handled is an embarrassment.

review_title: The American College - it'll be great after a management layoff
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Bryn Mawr, PA
pros: The benefits are very good and inexpensive, and the College offers a great deal of paid time off- about twenty five days a year for starting employees. The work day is also short- about seven and a half hours as opposed to the usual eight or nine.
cons: Senior management is VERY uninvolved with the "peasantry" as I call it- I have only met or spoken to the President once in the last 14 months, and the various department heads and departments don't communicate with each other or with the employees unless they're absolutely forced to. The compensation is low, and they have fought me tooth and nail every time I've asked for a raise.

review_title: There will always be people who don't like their job...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bryn Mawr, PA
pros: Strong compensation, benefits, and paid time off.  Improving culture.  Educational opportunities.  Growing community.  Encouragement to lead from the bottom-up.  Organization-wide incentive programs.  I love it here, but I do believe we need to go beyond just encouraging middle management to lead from the bottom-up; there is still quite a bit of micromanagement going on where senior leadership might as well be the project lead.
cons: The organization is still in a period of transition.  We have a lot of new people, and a lot of committed professional staff.  It's a complicated mix, but we have to take the good with the bad.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bryn Mawr, PA
pros: The location is convenient to the main line.
cons: Thankfully the President that started in 2013 is gone. Never walked the floors or listened. All he did was talk about his exercise routine and how much money he made on Berkshire stock.  The faculty has left or is leaving. Morale sucks. The last person who ran the Trustees Board should be ashamed of himself for not seeing we were losing MILLIONS of dollars and acting sooner.  We mostly eat at our desks.  HR waits for open enrollment each year until the last day- so much for caring about my family.  Almost half of senior management lives outside of PA!!  No one cares when no one watches.  I'm looking as are others but the reputation of the place has crashed in the past few years. I' m very sad about it.

review_title: It won't let me give zero stars...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bryn Mawr, PA
pros: PTO is the only redeeming quality, although I wouldn't be surprised if they did away with that soon as well
cons: The place is run by tyrants, including the new president. Upper management believes they are free to yell at and degrade employees. HR does nothing about legitimate complaints. An utter lack of respect towards fellow human beings. Why management thinks they can get away with it is the same reason this company is failing and will ultimately fade from memory in the world of financial services: it's top heavy. They lack general respect, and parade about as if they are doing a service to the industry. A short period of time here will show you that money is the only thing of import. Shiesty sales tactics. Employees DO NOT matter. The company DOES NOT promote from within. Take a job here, and you will quickly find that decision regrettable.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bryn Mawr, PA

review_title: Despicable! At a loss for words
job_title: Counselor in King of Prussia, PA

This individual cannot even write a legible e-mail. What's so disrespectful and cruel is the person's family is dying  management knew it and still went through with the termination. Think about it. There are more VP's than staff. Favoritism is rampant. Morale is close to suicidal with everyone walking on eggshells.

review_title: On the cusp of something good

review_title: Continued downward trend - stay away - layoffs continue - don't let it be you!
job_title: Administrative in Bryn Mawr, PA
pros: Good people work here, but make sure they earn your trust.  Some of the hires in the last year were solid.  It was good to see real professionals, but I left before they could shine.  My hope is that the machine did not eat them up and spit them out like many others in the past.
cons:
I need to start with the most important things to remember first.  This college is failing beyond reasonable recovery and is a toxic working environment.  Ask for full disclosure of the state of The College.  Ask a lot of questions in many different ways with the hope that you are receiving a complete understanding of your role and expectations.    Your role will likely change even before the ink on your first paycheck is dry.  Expect long working hours even when the rest of the college is a ghost town.  They have been eliminating positions in very high numbers for the past 24 months – older staff who know the business and newer staff just hired to help fix the failures of the past – very cut-throat – nobody is safe.
Their internal and external technology and content is behind the times for students, faculty and staff.  The new president is not a traditional college president and was an executive at New York Life – drives a new Porsche.  He was selected by trustees with money – the rich helping the rich get richer.  The new president will soon find that he made a poor career choice.  
There isn't enough meat on the bone to save The College from being buried by the competition and surviving past business decisions that allowed the sale of the original location of The College – it was beautiful!  They are now moving to King of Prussia and rely on tenants to afford the new location – one of the worst areas to commute in the greater Philadelphia area.  The new location is basically in the mall. The location strategy was based on saving money to keep the doors open – not convenient for students, faculty or staff.   
Enrollment is down and they rely on large companies to fill their “cattle shoot” of students.  If one company decides to pull their student funding, this college will not survive the impact.  Alumni are mad and most will never come back - and for good reason.  The College is charging alumni to keep their hard earned designations active - WHAT?!!!  Does a traditional college remove your degree?!  This was another strategy to save the college from closing its doors - poor decision and it has proven to fail (yet they continue with this model).  I heard they are now going to try subscription based learning model - please stop – the hole that you dug is too large to fill as it is.  Alumni are not coming back, but their fundraising unit will continue to ask alumni for money for “initiatives”.  In reality it helps to pay high “executive” salaries and keep the doors open just a little longer.  
In closing - it was the worst career move, but I am on my way back up the chain.  I left on my own and that was the best decision as there is no amount of money that would get me to go back to that place.  For your health and sanity alone…stay clear even if this is your only option.  There are always other options that will be better than accepting a position at this college.

job_title: in Bryn Mawr, PA
pros: My manager and senior leader seem to care about me as an employee and also handles all issues without involving unnecessary people.
cons:
The new president does not meet employee expectations.  Since he started he has bragged about his money and himself non-stop (bike trip, vacation time, never seen on campus - who has that much vacation time?), repeatedly praises inept people in weekly emails, hangs with the millennials he thinks makes him cool and blatantly ignores employees (the hard working little people) in the hallway.  Because of these reasons, the president has less than a handful of true followers as we all are blatantly aware of the truth.

There is huge concern about the future of the college.  In less than 2 years, the President has hired more senior leaders, promoted, demoted and fired good employees, and increased the staff population all when we are not bringing in half of the revenue that we used to.  We also have been spending money on unnecessary items such as Fitbits for all employees, free lunches just to get people to attend events, etc.  How we can spend as much money as we do, and turn around and ask for donations for a new building and continue to bleed out money on unnecessary things.  Where is our integrity?  

We already know we will not meet the 3-5-7, or even 1.  We think that if employees do not get a bonus, none of the senior leaders should get a bonus either.  Eventually, there will have to be layoffs, and these layoffs need to start at the top.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bryn Mawr, PA

Zero communication that continues to breed a silo mentality.
